actions.text: Hi! How are you feeling?
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.
So good to hear that you are doing well. What a wonderful feeling!
Sometimes we're up. Sometimes we're down. And sometimes we are neither up nor down...and that's totally okay!
Sorry to hear that you are not having a good day. It is completely normal to be going through a difficult time now. Remember that you are not alone. Here is an activity that might also help...
Here is something fun to help you let go of stress:
Do your children ever make you feel like screaming? Give yourself a 10-second pause.
Have you only got 30 seconds? Let's take a quick pause together. It might be helpful.

Do you sometimes feel your feelings are too much?
Talk to someone. 
Talk to someone you trust. Talk to a friend. Talk to family. Talk to a plant.
Get your worries off your chest and then let them go. Even if it’s just for a moment. 
How do you feel now?
A joy shared is twice the joy. A problem shared is half the problem.

Choose a song that reflects what you need in this moment. Do you need a gentle song to soothe your tired soul or an upbeat song to help you shake some stress out?

Make a space and move your body to the music. Remember to breathe while you move. Let your breath and the movement go together.

Even a few minutes of movement can be enough to release stress and lift your mood!
Choose a song that reflects what you need.
Sit down, close your eyes and listen to your breath as it goes in and out. Notice how you feel. When you are ready open your eyes again.
Breath in and out slowly 5 times. Then try responding in a calmer way.
Five deep breaths.
Listen to your breath.
When feelings are too much.
Millions of parents say this helps - A LOT.
Try this whenever you are feeling stressed and you need a break to reconnect.
Here is a short relaxation activity for you:
Do you ever feel something so strongly that you want to run away from it? Here's a short activity that might help!
This activity uses the magic power of three breaths to stay connected and relaxed.
Here's an activity to relax your body:
Here is a quick relaxation activity...

Sit down and close your eyes.
How many sounds can you hear? Listen to the sounds inside and outside the room. Count them on your fingers.
After ten seconds, how many fingers do you have up? What sounds did you hear?
Try again for another ten seconds. Did you hear any new sounds? Did you hear any sounds inside your own body? Notice how you feel now.
Breathe in to the count of three.

Instead of moving away from the feeling, let’s move towards it for a moment.
It’s ok. Close your eyes if you feel comfortable. Take a deep breath.

Become curious. Where are you feeling it in your body? Is it hot or cold? Hard or soft? Tight or loose?
Ask yourself some questions. What is it telling me? What does it need? How can I be kind to myself in this moment?

If your mind starts to wander, it’s normal. Just bring it back to the feeling. Keep breathing and feeling.
Reassure yourself. It’s ok to feel. Feeling is healing!

Notice your connection with the ground beneath you.
What parts of your body touch the ground? What parts of your body don’t? 
Notice where it feels warm and where it feels cool.
Feel the ground underneath you supporting you. Let your body sink into the support of the ground.

Breathe in to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.
Breath out to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.
Breathe in to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.
Breath out to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.
Breathe in to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.
Breath out to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.

Sit comfortably and close your eyes if you can.
Imagine a golden ring scanning your body from your feet to your head. 
Pay attention as it moves up and down your body. Are there any areas that feel tense? Numb? Painful? 
Focus on those areas for a moment. Breathe in to the area and when you breathe out, try to let go of any tension or pain. 
Do this for a few breaths. 
Open your eyes. How does your body feel now?

Try this next time you find yourself lying in bed unable to sleep!
Listen to the sounds.
Connection with the ground.
How do you feel now? Do you feel any different? Deep breathing helps our whole body and mind to calm down.
Notice how you feel now.
Dealing with difficult feelings.
Body relaxation.
It’s ok to feel. Feeling is healing!
Try this next time you find yourself lying in bed unable to sleep!
Let’s use the magic power of three to stay present and relax. At the end of a tough day, thinking of three things to be grateful for can help us find the courage to try again tomorrow.
Here's a short relaxation activity to end the day:

Let's take a moment to stop what you are doing and connect with your breath.  

What is one thing you can be grateful for right now?
What is one thing that brings you happiness?
What is one thing that you love?

They don't have to be big. Sometimes the small things in life count the most!

At the end of the day, take a minute to think about the day.  
Think about one positive or fun thing you did.
Praise yourself for one thing you did well today.
Think of one thing you can do differently tomorrow. 
Think of one thing that you are grateful for. 

You are a star!
Do you sometimes feel like you are getting everything wrong?  Here's a short activity that might help!
The magic power of three.
Close your eyes and think about the day. Name 1 thing that you are grateful for. Name 1 thing that you did well. Name 1 think that you love. You earned a goodnight of sleep!

Think of one thing you did today that you don’t feel proud of. What can you do differently tomorrow?
And wrap your arms around your body and give yourself a hug.
Now, take a moment to think over the day. Think of one thing you did today that you are proud of.
Wrap your arms around your body and give yourself a hug.

It’s ok. You are doing your best so be kind to yourself. Get some rest and try again tomorrow!
Connect with your breath.
Take a minute to think about the day.
End of the day.
You are a star!
You earned a goodnight of sleep!
Be kind to yourself.
It’s ok. You are doing your best so be kind to yourself. Get some rest and try again tomorrow!
We are now spending a lot more time online. Being connected helps us stay positive…but it also presents risks and dangers.
Would you like to learn more about this tip?
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.
That's okay! You can always type "Help" at anytime if you need any support with your children. Chat to you later!
Here's a video to help you keep yourself safe online.
Here's an audio message to help you keep yourself safe online.

Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit! Digital parenting is just like parenting in the real world. You have taken a BIG STEP to keeping your child safe online. Good for you!
Remember you can always type "Help" if you ever want more parenting tips or support. Chat to you later!

Here are 5 tips that can help you keep yourself safe online:

1. Learn about the risks and dangers
2. Quick tech fixes
3. Create healthy and safe online habits
4. Maintain privacy
5. Report and seek help

To learn more about one of these, type "1" to "5". You can also type "N" to stop this tip.
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

1. Learn about risks and dangers

• Adults targeting people for sexual purposes on social media, gaming, and messaging platforms.
• Harmful content – like violence, hating women, hating foreigners, encouraging suicide and self-harm, misinformation, pornography
• Sharing personal information and sexual photos or videos.
• Cyberbullying from other people and strangers.

5. Report and seek help

Report to SAFERKIDSPH and BANTAYBATA163 and the Child Helpline to get support if you experience online violence or other things that are not acceptable.

SAFERKIDSPH: https://www.saferkidsph.org/
BANTAYBATA163: https://corporate.abs-cbn.com/lingkodkapamilya/bantay-bata/about
IWF portals: https://report.iwf.org.uk/en
Child Helpline: https://www.childhelplineinternational.org/

4. Maintain privacy

Keep personal information private, especially from strangers. – some people are not who they say they are!

2. Quick tech fixes:

• Turn on SafeSearch on your browser to filter adult content.
https://www.internetmatters.org/blog/parental-controls/entertainment-search-engines/
• Set up parental controls.
https://www.internetmatters.org/parental-controls/
• Set up strict privacy settings on online apps and games.
 https://www.internetmatters.org/blog/parental-controls/social-media/
• Cover webcams when not in use.

3. Create healthy and safe online habits:

You can also create healthy and safe online habits like creating device-free spaces and times in your house (eating, playing, schoolwork, and sleeping).
Remember that what goes online stays online (messages, photos, and videos).

Please select another number if you want to learn another way to protect yourself online:

1. Learn about the risks and dangers
2. Quick tech fixes
3. Create healthy and safe online habits
4. Maintain privacy
5. Report and seek help

You can also type "N" to stop this tip.
Routines will make your children feel safe and secure. Try to have regular mealtimes and bedtimes. Remember to schedule One-on-One time with your children, too!
Did you know that teens actually like having responsibilities? It makes them feel more independent and grown up. Allow your teen to choose a special job that helps out.
Routines will make your children feel safe and secure. Try to have regular mealtimes and bedtimes. Remember to schedule One-on-One time with your children, too!
When you teach your children about safe distancing, you keep your whole family safe. You keep others safe, too!
As your teen shows more responsibility, you can also give them extra privileges. Try to share responsibilities equally amongst women/men and girls/boys. Praise your teen whenever they do their job!

You can even make hand washing into a game where children earn points whenever they wash their hands with soap before and after meals. The one with the most points can win a simple, free reward like extra One-on-One Time.

1. Crying a lot

7. Stubborn or fussy

flow.name: PLH - Content - Tips - Difficult behaviours survey

actions.text: Our children and teens are now spending a lot more time online. Being connected helps them stay positive…but it also presents risks and dangers.
Would you like to learn more about this tip?
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.
Here's a video to help you keep your children safe online.
Here's an audio message to help you keep your children safe online.
That's okay! You can always type "Help" at anytime if you need any support with your children. Chat to you later!

Here are 6 tips that can help you keep your children safe online:

1. Learn about the risks and dangers
2. Quick tech fixes
3. Create healthy and safe online habits
4. Spend time with your child online
5. Build open communication
6. Report and seek help

To learn more about one of these, type "1" to "6". You can also type "N" to stop this tip.
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

1. Learn about risks and dangers

• Adults targeting children for sexual purposes on social media, gaming, and messaging platforms.
• Harmful content – like violence, hating women, hating foreigners, encouraging suicide and self-harm, misinformation, pornography
• Teens sharing personal information and sexual photos or videos of themselves.
• Cyberbullying from other young people and strangers.

2. Tech fixes to protect your children online:

• Turn on SafeSearch on your browser to filter adult content.
https://www.internetmatters.org/blog/parental-controls/entertainment-search-engines/
• Set up parental controls.
https://www.internetmatters.org/parental-controls/
• Set up strict privacy settings on online apps and games.
 https://www.internetmatters.org/blog/parental-controls/social-media/
• Cover webcams when not in use.

3. Create healthy and safe online habits:

Involve your child or teen in creating family tech agreements about healthy device use.
Create device-free spaces and times in your house
(eating, playing, schoolwork, and sleeping).

Child tech agreement: https://www.esafety.gov.au/sites/default/files/2020-01/Our%20Family%20Tech%20Agreement_0.pdf
Teen tech agreement: https://www.childnet.com/ufiles/Family-Agreement.pdf

Help your child learn how to keep personal information private, especially from strangers – some people are not who they say they are!
Remind your children that what goes online stays online (messages, photos, and videos).
 Actively supervise children’s time online, including computers, smartphones, and tablets.
This does not mean we should ban our children from spending time online. It just means that we need to learn how to protect them in a new world.

4. Spend time with your child or teen online

Get to know how your child experiences the digital world.
Explore websites, social media, games, and apps together.
Talk to your teen on how to report things that aren't OK.

Common Sense Media has great advice for apps, games and entertainment for different ages.
https://www.commonsensemedia.org/app-reviews

5. Build open communication and trusting relationships
Tell your children that if they experience something online (or anywhere) that makes them feel upset, uncomfortable, or scared, they can talk to you and you will not get mad or punish them.

6. Report and seek help

Report to SAFERKIDSPH and BANTAYBATA163 and the Child Helpline to get support if you or your children experience online violence or other things that are not acceptable.

SAFERKIDSPH: https://www.saferkidsph.org/
BANTAYBATA163: https://corporate.abs-cbn.com/lingkodkapamilya/bantay-bata/about
IWF portals: https://report.iwf.org.uk/en
Child Helpline: https://www.childhelplineinternational.org/

Please select another number if you want to learn another way to protect your child online:

2. Quick tech fixes
3. Create healthy and safe online habits
4. Spend time with your child online
5. Build open communication
6. Report and seek help

You can also type "N" to stop this tip.
Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit! Keeping your child safe online is just like in the real world. You have taken a BIG STEP to making this happen. Good for you!
Remember you can always type "Help" if you ever want more parenting tips or support. Chat to you later!
All children, including those living with disabilities, need love, respect and time especially at difficult times.
Would you like to learn more about this tip?
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

Here's an audio message to help you support children living with disabilities.
That's okay! You can always type "Help" if you want to learn more about how to support children living with disabilities.

Here is a link to disability services in your area that may also be helpful: [INSERT LOCAL LINK]
Chat later!

Here are 6 simple tips that you can do to support children living with disabilities: 

1. Keep your child safe and well
2. Try to understand what they are feeling
3. Communicate and talk with them
4. Praise them!
5. Make things that you do the same every day to help them feel secure
6. Ask for help if you can

Type "1" to "6" to learn more about each tip. Type "N" to stop this tip.
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

Step 1. Keep your child safe and well 

• Keep your country's COVID-19 rules, and also help your child to be active - do whatever exercise you can with them inside or outside your home
• Keep emergency contact numbers somewhere easy to see

Step 5. Make daily plans to help them feel secure

• Having things that are the same each day helps children feel secure and safe.
• Make a daily plan that includes some things they like to do.
• Help your child connect to friends and family members through phone, writing cards, or drawing pictures.

Step 2. Try to understand how they are feeling

• Accept your child’s feelings.
• Tell them that you love them
• Praise them for being good and for trying to be good!

• Give your child choices: this gives them a sense of control and builds self-esteem.
• Use simple language and clear instructions. If words aren't good for them, try gestures and pictures.

Step 4. Praise them!

• Praise them for behaving well, and for trying. 
• Focus on what they can do, not what they can't.
• Only help children when they need it. It is also good to build independence!

Step 6. Ask for help if you can
• Share the load with other adult family members.
•  You are not alone! Keep connected with people who understand your situation.

Step 3. Communicate and talk with your child

• Get down to your child’s level when you speak. 
• Look at them and smile.
• Give them time to tell you or show you what they think.
• Tell your child that you understand

• Share your challenges AND your successes.
• It is normal to feel stressed, frustrated, and afraid at this time.
• Be kind to yourself and take a break when you need to!
Well done for adding another tool to your Parenting Toolkit! Children living with disabilities need love, respect and time – just like any other child.

Please select another number if you want to learn more about how to support children living with disabilities:

6. Ask for help if you can

flows.name: PLH - Content - Time - One on one time baby

actions.text: Would you like to learn more about this tip?
Invest in One-on-One Time! The more time you spend with your children, the more likely they will listen to you and behave well at other times. It really works!
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.
That's okay! You can always type "Help" if you want to receive more tips about how to manage your child's behaviour.
Here's a video about spending one-on-one time with your baby!
Here's an audio message about spending one-on-one time with your baby!

The first 1000 days of life are a window of opportunity for your baby. It is when their brain develops faster than any other time in their life. When you spend time with your baby, you build a healthy attachment between you both that will make them feel secure and loved.

It is normal to struggle to think of what to do with our babies, especially when it seems they just eat, sleep, cry, poop, and repeat. It can be especially challenging when your baby is very young and not able to talk to you.
Would you like to learn more?
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.
That's okay! You can always type "Help" whenever you want to learn more about how to spend One-on-One Time with your baby. Chat to you later!

Here are 7 easy tips to make One-on-One Time with your baby a success:

1. Do it every day
2. Be close to your baby
3. Let your baby take the lead
4. Observe and listen to your child
5. Play with your baby
6. Talk to your baby
7. You can have quality time with your baby anytime! 

To learn more about one of these tips, type "1" to "7". You can also type "N" to move on.
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

1. Do it every day!
Try to spend time playing with your baby every day for at least 20 minutes where you are giving them your full attention. Choose a time when you are unlikely to be interrupted. Switch off the television and put away phones.

2. Be close to your child. 
Skin-to-skin contact is especially important for new-borns and infants. For older toddlers, make sure you are at the same level as they are.

3. Let your baby take the lead
Children need to do things in their own time. Try to give them time to explore and be patient. Remember that the world is brand new to your child!

4. Observe your child. 
See what facial expressions your child is making. Notice what your child is interested in or looking at.

Give just enough help to let it be the child’s achievement. It is okay to play alongside and copy what they are doing but try to let them keep the initiative. If your child gets frustrated, you can reassure your child by gently stroking their back.
Listen to the sounds or words your child is making. You can even make the same sounds by copying your child!

5. Play with your baby
Babies learn through play! Help your child explore the world through the five senses. Let your child use all of their senses when exploring the world. Sometimes when you read to your child, your child will want to put the book in their mouth. That is okay!

6. Talk to your baby
Start talking to your baby from the moment they are born (even before when they are in the womb). Did you know your baby can even recognise their name at a very early age? Try saying your baby's name and notice how they respond!
Here is a comic about spending one-on-one time with your baby!

It is okay for your child to want to do many different things. Your child’s attention may wander to many different things during One-on-One Time. Anything that is happening can grab their attention: the sound of a car, the feeling of a breeze from a fan, feelings in the body. Just keep your attention on your child.

Use words to describe actions, colours, shapes, numbers, sizes, textures, temperatures, tastes, sounds, and anything else that is happening. Speak with enthusiasm when describing what your child is doing.

7. You can have quality time with your baby anytime! 
Look for ways you can connect with your baby playfully during feeding, bathing, and dressing. You can even make bedtime a fun and nurturing experience for you and your baby in a calm way.

Please select another number if you want to learn more about how to spend One-on-One Time with your baby:

1. Do it every day
2. Be close to your baby
3. Let your baby take the lead
4. Observe and listen to your child
5. Play with your baby
6. Talk to your baby
7. You can have quality time with your baby anytime! 

You can also type "N" to move on.
Congratulations! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit. Quality time with your children is the best gift that you can ever give them.
Would you like some suggestions for activities to do with your baby?
That's okay! You can always type "Help" at anytime if you need an activity. Chat to you later!
